Generator.name: Xper3

Representation.Label: Solitary flower
Representation.Detail: It is a flower that is not part of an inflorescence.

Representation.Label: Absence (inflorescence)
Representation.Detail: Several flowers closely grouped together to form an efficient structured unit; the grouping or arrangement of flowers on a plant.

Representation.Label: Single cluster (or raceme)
Representation.Detail: An inflorescence consisting of a main axis, bearing single flowers alternately or spirally on talks (pedicels) approximately equal length. The apical growing point continues to be active so there is usually no terminal flower and the youngest branches or flowers are nearest the apex. This mode of growth is known as monopodial.

Representation.Label: Spike
Representation.Detail: An inflorescence of simple racemose type in which the flowers are stalkless (sessile)

Representation.Label: Spadix
Representation.Detail: A spike of flowers on a swollen, fleshy axis.

Representation.Label: Panicle
Representation.Detail: Strictly a branched raceme, with each branch bearing a further raceme of flowers. More loosely applies to any complex, branched inflorescence.

Representation.Label: Spikelet
Representation.Detail: A small spike, as in grasses.

Representation.Label: Bilateral cyme
Representation.Detail: An inflorescence in which each terminal growing point produces a flower. Subsequent growth is therefore from a lateral growing point, the oldest being at the apex, or center, if flat.

Representation.Label: Helicoid unilateral cyme
Representation.Detail: Coiled like a spring.

Representation.Label: Scorpioid unilateral cyme
Representation.Detail: Curved to one side like a scorpion's tail.

Representation.Label: Thyrse
Representation.Detail: Densely branched, broadest in the middle and which the mode of branching is cymose.

Representation.Label: Umbel
Representation.Detail: An umbrella-shaped inflorescence with all the stalks (pedicels) arising from the top of the main stem. Umbels are sometimes compound, with all the stalks arising from the same point and giving rise to several terminal flower stalks.

Representation.Label: Capitulum
Representation.Detail: An inflorescence consisting of a head of closely packed stalkless flowers.

Representation.Label: Corymb
Representation.Detail: A rounded or flat-topped inflorescence of racemose type, in which the lower (outer) flower stalks are longer than the upper (inner) ones, so that all the flowers are about the same level.

Representation.Label: Cyathium
Representation.Detail: A cyathium is a cup- or bowl-shaped structure formed from fused bracts, and enclosing the tiny flowers.

Representation.Label: Type catkin
Representation.Detail: A pendulous inflorescence of simple, usually unisexual flower.

Representation.Label: Type syconium
Representation.Detail: A syconium is the type of inflorescence borne by figs (genus Ficus), formed by an enlarged, fleshy, hollow receptacle with multiple ovaries on the inside surface.

Representation.Label: Inflorescence bract
Representation.Detail: A bract is a leaf, often modified or reduced, which subtends a flower or inflorescence in its axil. A spathe is a large bract subtending and often ensheating an inflorescence. Applied only on the monocotyledons.

Representation.Label: Presence and not in spathe form
More than one well developed spathe
Sex of flowers
Representation.Detail: Unisexual: having either stamens or pistils but not both. Bisexual: denoting a single flower that contains functional staminate and pistillate structures

Representation.Label: Unisexual and dioecious
Representation.Detail: Dioecious: having the male and female reproductive organs in separate individuals.

Representation.Label: Unisexual and plant monoecious
Representation.Detail: Monoecious: having both the male and female reproductive organs separated in the same individual

Representation.Label: Symmetry of the flower
Representation.Detail: The symmetry is the quality of being made up of exactly similar parts facing each other or around an axis.

Representation.Label: Irregular flower and without symmetry
Representation.Detail: Irregular is not divisible into halves by an indefinite number of longitudinal planes.

Representation.Label: Radial (actinomorphic)
Representation.Detail: Radially symmetrical, with more than one plane of symmetry. Also called regular flowers.

Representation.Label: Bilateral (zygomorphic)
Representation.Detail: Not divisible into halves by an indefinite number of longitudinal planes. Also called irregular flowers.

Representation.Label: Floral bract
Representation.Detail: A bract is a a leaf, often modified or reduced, which subtends a flower or inflorescence in its axil.

Representation.Label: Floral peduncle
Representation.Detail: It is a stem supporting an inflorescence, or after fecundation, an infructescence.

Representation.Label: Floral receptacle
Representation.Detail: The receptacle is the thickened part of a stem (pedicel) from which the flower organs grow. In some accessory fruits, for example the pome and strawberry, the receptacle gives rise to the edible part of the fruit.

Representation.Label: More or less flat (or slightly convex or concave)
Strongly concave (hypanthium)
Representation.Detail: The hypanthium is a cup-shaped enlargement of the floral receptacle or the base of the floral parts, which often enlarges and surrounds the fruits, e.g., the fleshy tissue in rose-hips.

Representation.Label: Nectariferous spur
Representation.Detail: The spur is a hollow, usually rather conical, projection from the base of a sepal, petal, or fused corolla. It can secrete nectar.

Representation.Label: Presence, more than two per flower
Resupined flower
Representation.Detail: Resupine is lying on the back.

Representation.Label: Differenciation calyx/corolla
Representation.Detail: Calyx is a collective term for all a flower's sepals. Corolla is all all the petals of a flower. It is normally colored. A tepal is a perianth-segment that is not clearly distinguishable as either a sepal or a petal.

Representation.Label: Color uniformity of tepals (or if calyx and corolla concolors)
Tepals all of the same color
At least one tepal of a different color
Background color of tepals (with or without patterns)
Epicalyx
Representation.Detail: The epicalyx is a whorl of sepal-like appendages resembling the calyx but outside the true calyx.

Representation.Label: Calyx
Representation.Detail: Collective term for all a flower's petal.

Representation.Label: Calyx reduced to scales, hairs or bristles
Representation.Detail: A scale is a small, often membranous, reduced leaf frequently found covering buds and bulbs.

Representation.Label: Yes (gamosepalous or synsepalous flower)
Representation.Detail: With sepals fused, at least at the base.

Representation.Label: Color uniformity of the calyx if petaloid (and apetalous flowers)
Sepals all of the same color
At least one sepal of a different color
Background color of sepals if petaloid (with or without patterns and apetal flowers)
Color of calyx if well developed and not petaloid
Corolla
Representation.Detail: Corolla is all all the petals of a flower. It is normally colored.

Representation.Label: "Papillonaceous" corolla
Representation.Detail: Having a corolla (as in the bean or pea) with usually five petals that include a large upper petal enclosing two lateral wings and a lower carina of two united petals. They are flowers with the characteristic irregular and butterfly-like corolla found in many, though not all, plants of the species-rich Faboideae subfamily of legumes.

Representation.Label: Bilabiate 2/3 corolla
Representation.Detail: Bilabiate is two-lipped

Representation.Label: Petals all of the same color
At least one petal of a different colour
"Ventral" petal transformed into labellum
Representation.Detail: A labellum is a central petal at the base of an orchid flower, typically larger than the other petals and of a different shape.

Representation.Label: Didynamous androecium (if 4 stamen)
Representation.Detail: Having two stamen longer than others.

Representation.Label: Tetradynamous androecium (if 6 stamen)
Representation.Detail: Having four stamen longer than others.

Representation.Label: Staminodes
Representation.Detail: A staminode is a sterile, often reduced or modified stamen, and sometimes transformed in nectary.

Representation.Label: Introrse
Representation.Detail: Directing and opening inward toward the center of the flower.

Representation.Label: Extrorse
Representation.Detail: Opening away from the axis of growth towards the corolla.

Representation.Label: Pollen aggregation into pollinia
Representation.Detail: Pollinia are a mass of pollen grains produced by one anther-lobe, cohering together and transported as a single unit during pollination, as in the orchids.

Representation.Label: Appearance of calyx if well developed and not petaloid
Scarious
Representation.Detail: Scarious is dry and membranous, with a dried-up appearance.

Representation.Label: Diaphanous
Representation.Detail: Diaphanous is light, delicate, and translucent.

Representation.Label: Scarious
Representation.Detail: Scarious is dry and membranous, with a dried-up appearance.

Representation.Label: Diaphanous
Representation.Detail: Diaphanous is light, delicate, and translucent.

Representation.Label: Gynophore
Representation.Detail: Stalk of a carpel or gynoecium.
